answer_html: \(\displaystyle V(2)=\frac{32}{3}\) and this is the maximal volume as required.
answer_latex: $\displaystyle V(2)=\frac{32}{3}$ and this is the maximal volume as required.
hints_html:
Try drawing a picture. The object we are looking for is a rectangular prism with an open top. What is the volume of such an object? What is the surface area?

Setting l to be the length, w to be the width and h to be the height, we have

\[\begin{aligned} V &= lwh \\ SA &= 2lh + 2wh + lw \\ l &= 2w\end{aligned}\]

where for the surface area above, we keep in mind that our box has no top.

Since this is an optimization problem, which function are you trying to maximize? Which functions are the constraints?

Try drawing a picture. The object we are looking for is a rectangular
prism with an open top. What is the volume of such an object? What is
the surface area?

Setting \emph{l} to be the length, \emph{w} to be the width and \emph{h}
to be the height, we have

\begin{align*}
V &= lwh \\
SA &= 2lh + 2wh + lw \\
l &= 2w
\end{align*}

where for the surface area above, we keep in mind that our box has no
top.

Since this is an optimization problem, which function are you trying to
maximize? Which functions are the constraints?
hints_raw:
Try drawing a picture. The object we are looking for is a rectangular prism with an open top. What is the volume of such an object? What is the surface area?
Setting ''l'' to be the length, ''w'' to be the width and ''h'' to be the height, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
V &= lwh \\
SA &= 2lh + 2wh + lw \\
l &= 2w
\end{align}
</math>

where for the surface area above, we keep in mind that our box has no top.  

Since this is an optimization problem, which function are you trying to maximize?  Which functions are the constraints?
sols_html:
We will need the following formulas:

The volume of the box is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle V = l w h\end{aligned}\]

Where l is the length of the base of the box, w is the width, and h is the height.

The material will form the outside of the box, which is the same as its surface area. The surface area of an open box is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle SA = 2lh + 2wh + lw\end{aligned}\]

With l, w, and h as before.

We also know that the length of the base of the box is twice its width. In an equation, this means

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle l = 2w\end{aligned}\]

We can plug this into our volume and surface area formulas to get

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle V = 2w^2h\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle SA = 6wh +2w^2\end{aligned}\]

We know one more fact. Because we have \(24 m^2\) of material, the formula for surface area must be equal to 24, or

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 24 = 6wh +2w^2\end{aligned}\]

Isolating for h yields

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle h = \frac{24-2w^{2}}{6w}\end{aligned}\]

(NOTE: In this step we are assuming that the width is not equal to zero, which makes sense given the physical limitations of our problem, that is, boxes have positive dimensions). Plugging this into our formula for volume yields

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle V = 2w^2h = 2w^{2} \cdot \frac{24-2w^{2}}{6w} = \frac{w(24-2w^{2})}{3} = 8w - \frac{2}{3}w^{3}\end{aligned}\]

We wish to optimize V. Now that is has only one variable, differentiating yields

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle V' = 8 - 2w^{2}\end{aligned}\]

Setting this equal to 0 and solving gives \(w^{2} = 4\) and thus that \(w=2\) (where we note again that dimensions must be positive). Looking at the derivative of volume, a sign chart tells us that\(V'(w) > 0\) when \(w < 2\) and \(V'(w) > 0\) when \(w < 2\). Hence, we have a maximum at w=2. The volume of the box with this width is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle V(2) = 8(2) - \frac{2}{3}(2)^{3} = 16 - \frac{16}{3} = \frac{32}{3}\end{aligned}\]

and this is the maximal volume as required.
sols_raw:
We will need the following formulas:

The volume of the box is given by
: <math>\displaystyle V = l w h</math>
Where ''l'' is the length of the base of the box, ''w'' is the width, and ''h'' is the height.  

The material will form the outside of the box, which is the same as its surface area.  The surface area of an open box is given by
: <math> \displaystyle SA = 2lh + 2wh + lw</math>
With ''l'', ''w'', and ''h'' as before.  

We also know that the length of the base of the box is twice its width.  In an equation, this means
: <math> \displaystyle l = 2w </math>

We can plug this into our volume and surface area formulas to get
: <math> \displaystyle V = 2w^2h </math>
: <math>\displaystyle SA = 6wh +2w^2</math>

We know one more fact.  Because we have <math>24 m^2</math> of material, the formula for surface area must be equal to 24, or

: <math>\displaystyle 24 = 6wh +2w^2 </math>

Isolating for ''h'' yields

: <math>\displaystyle h = \frac{24-2w^{2}}{6w} </math>

(NOTE: In this step we are assuming that the width is not equal to zero, which makes sense given the physical limitations of our problem, that is, boxes have positive dimensions). Plugging this into our formula for volume yields

: <math> \displaystyle V = 2w^2h = 2w^{2} \cdot \frac{24-2w^{2}}{6w} = \frac{w(24-2w^{2})}{3} = 8w - \frac{2}{3}w^{3}  </math>

We wish to optimize ''V''. Now that is has only one variable, differentiating yields

: <math> \displaystyle V' = 8 - 2w^{2} </math>

Setting this equal to 0 and solving gives <math> w^{2} = 4 </math> and thus that <math> w=2 </math> (where we note again that dimensions must be positive). Looking at the derivative of volume, a sign chart tells us that<math> V'(w) > 0 </math> when <math> w < 2 </math> and <math> V'(w) > 0 </math> when <math> w < 2 </math>. Hence, we have a maximum at ''w''=2. The volume of the box with this width is

: <math> \displaystyle V(2) = 8(2) - \frac{2}{3}(2)^{3} = 16 - \frac{16}{3} = \frac{32}{3}  </math>

and this is the maximal volume as required.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.

If 24m2 of material is available to make a rectangular storage container with an open top, and if the length of its base is twice the width, find the largest possible volume of the rectangular storage container. Please justify that your answer gives indeed the largest possible volume.
statement_latex:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}

If 24m\textsuperscript{2} of material is available to make a rectangular
storage container with an open top, and if the length of its base is
twice the width, find the largest possible volume of the rectangular
storage container. Please justify that your answer gives indeed the
largest possible volume.
statement_raw:
'''''Full-Solution Problems.''' In questions 2-8, justify your answers and '''show all your work.''' Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.''

If 24m<sup>2</sup> of material is available to make a rectangular storage container with an open top, and if the length of its base is twice the width, find the largest possible volume of the rectangular storage container.
Please justify that your answer gives indeed the largest possible volume.
